name: John_Hempton
tweet: @StockJabber Instead I muted him because his irrationality was driving him to political views that were anathema (and probably a manifestation of what was happening).  A good guy would have noticed and helped.

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @StockJabber moreover I know how it happens. He was driven irrational by losses (something more widespread than we care to admit).   Then he stole to play double-or-nothing.   That is deeply psychological.  I should have  a. spotted it  b. told him to snap out  I did neither.

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @StockJabber Because I knew him personally (and am shocked and saddened). But you are right that there are plenty of worse injustices in the world.

tweet: @MuzzaFerguson @alexbhturnbull looks like murder to me. name: John_Hempton
tweet: @KM_Kito @InfoRatioed @quantian1 there is a lot of graft, corruption, abuse.  I spend my days chasing crims of type 1 in the above topology.  Crims of type 2 (the Protestant crimes) are I think less common, but more likely to be caught and if caught plead guilty.

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @InfoRatioed @quantian1 the great Protestant slogan is "there but for the grace of god go I."  It is a reminder that all people drift. Some more than others, but all people.  I see this as a protestant crime.  2/2

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @InfoRatioed @quantian1 The line should always be miles away. But I divide crimes like this into  two types:  a. people who start evil and whose intent is to rip people off, and  b. protestant crimes, where people start well enough but by circumstance drift...  1/2

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @quantian1 the more I think about this  the less happy I am.  Markets are horrid places, and losses make people irrational.  Even good people can be made desperate by losses, and when this bubble/cycle is over there will be a lot of losses.  This is not good.

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @michaeljames947 I realise I elided the difference between the Queen and her representative. But the same issue would then become about sacking the GG.

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @DangInvestor @michaeljames947 The power vested in our God-Prime Minister the Hon Mr Tony Abbott.  But whatever.

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @michaeljames947 Resepectfully Michael I just disagree with you here.  7/7

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @michaeljames947 But what I think will quietly (!) happen is the Crown would delay on the advice until they were appraised of the investigation.  An elderly Queen taking advice from her successor seems entirely appropriate here.  6/n

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @michaeljames947 The reserve powers are a thing for PRECISELY the time when the elected head of government is acting illegally.  In this case it may be that the Queen will (privately) take counsel from some law professors or the like.  5/n

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @michaeljames947 This is the sort of point where reserve powers do apply. In America the President just sacks the head of the FBI. (Don't laugh, it happened.)  In Australia the Prime Minister needs to ask the Crown to do that.  4/n

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @michaeljames947 So one day - in the middle of a hot investigation the Prime Minister comes in and says to the Governor General he wants to sack the Commissioner and appoint someone more agreeable to him.  3/n

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @michaeljames947 The Commissioners (and Deputy Commissioners) under the Act are appointed by the Crown.    https://t.co/KEROyNL1ie  2/n

name: John_Hempton
tweet: @michaeljames947 The reserve powers are still a thing.  Lets run a hypothetical.   Suppose the head of the Commonwealth Police is investigating a crime in a hypothetical Prime Minister's office.  Should he inform the crown?  I think the answer is yes - but you may differ.  1/2
